description.narrative: The project supports the Royal Government of Cambodia (RGC) in establishing an effective early warning system (EWS) for the timely preparation for extreme events, as well as climate resilient development planning.

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

5. % change in agriculture productivity in select communities
The Mid Term Review conducted in April 2019 revealed the complexity of this indicator, as (a) there is no baseline study on agriculture productivity and (b) the need of conducting a study on agricultural productivity after the farmers training. This indicator is considered mostly complex and challenging and recommended to be changed. However, a series of activities are being developed to increase agricultural productivity.
The project initiative on establishing Drought Info Hub trained 50 local agricultural co-operative leaders in drought-resistant agricultural techniques (such as water conservation and crop diversification) using a train-the-trainer methodology; and further trained 450 farmers in drought-resistant agricultural techniques. These activities were carried out to increase agricultural productivity.

The training also introduced addVANTAGE software and system, which is developed by ADCON, as our supplier for AWS installation. - In December 2018, 12 hydrologists and staffs of Department of Hydrology and River Works of MOWRAM were trained on the operationalization of automatic hydro stations for surface water and ground water, for software and hardware. - In April 2019, five staffs of DOM were trained on O&M for AWS and 5 staffs of DHRW were trained on O&M for AHS.

1. 6 national, sub-national and sectoral plans have been supported by the climate infrastructure and system established by the project: 1) National Curriculum for Farmers Field School for MAFF, which is part of Climate Change Action Plan of MAFF. 2) Disaster Risk Reduction Plan in Agriculture Sector of MAFF has been developed through use of climate infrastructure and system supported by the project. 3) Drought Manual, which is used as a national reference for local level implementation of drought risk management 4) Disaster Risk Reduction Plan 2019-2023 of National Committee for Disaster Management. 5) Standard Operational Procedure for EWS in Cambodia. 6) Common Alert Protocol for Early Warning System (EWS)1294 in Cambodia.
2. A new Standard Operational Procedure (SOP) for Early Warning System in Cambodia was developed and tested. This new SOP was developed by expanding scope of the existing SOP, which focused mainly on floods early warning system. As the project focused on strengthening collaboration of key EWS stakeholders in the country (MOWRAM, MAFF and NCDM), the project helped improved the SOP which now caters to a wider need of climate information in Cambodia beyond floods and includes multi-hazard early warning system. The new SOP was developed after rigorous consultations involving NCDM, MOWRAM, MAFF and Mekong River Commissions, from May 2019 – December 2019.
This SOP is an integrated, multi-hazard SOP and advocates the use of EWS1294 as a national system. It is a manifestation of the document developed by World Bank and ADPC in 2014 on Road Map for establishing End-to-End Early Warning Strategy from regional, national, provincial and commune levels covering both human capacity and technical consideration
3. A total of 12 DOM and 12 DHRW staff members have been trained on advanced meteorological and hydrological forecasting.
4. 9 following training courses (with their corresponding course content and case studies, where applicable), have been implemented:
1) Basic and advance meteorological forecasting 2) Basic and advance hydrological forecasting 3) Operation and maintenance of automatic weather stations & addVANTAGE software system (for DOM) 4) Surface water and ground water monitoring stations software and hardware training (for DOHRW) 5) Integrated Water Resource Management System, GIS-based risk analysis through use of data generated by the stations. 6) GIS data management training for hydrological and meteorological application. 7) Drought Management Manual was developed following the request of Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries based on the need for comprehensive drought training manual for agriculture extension officers and farmers, integrating climate, GIS, meteorological and hydrological information for drought management (in Khmer and English) 8) Farmers field school curriculum/training manual was developed in 2019, to be used as a national standard for farmers field school integrating climate information for drought management (in English and Khmer) 9) Cambodia-specific training modules for meteorological forecasting were developed in May 2019 (English).
5. A survey for farmers was conducted by the project to reflect on applied knowledge from training activities and it pointed to the fact that there is increased productivity in farming activity. A series of activities were implemented to increase agricultural productivity - as follows: The partnership established with Dan Church Aid on establishing Drought Info Hub trained 223 local agricultural co-operative leaders in drought-resistant agricultural techniques (such as water conservation and crop diversification) using a train-the-trainer methodology; and further trained 2,113 farmers (1,343 female) in drought-resistant agricultural techniques. This is an increase from the last reporting period. These activities were carried out to increase agricultural productivity. In 2019 the partnership also completed a study on the change behavior of farmers in the areas covered (and not covered) under Drought Info Hub. The research conducted by UNDP and DCA examined DRAT implementation by farmers in Takeo, Kampong Chhang, and Battambang Province to assess the uptake and impact of DRAT. A total of 72 farmers were employed as respondents (26 in Battambang, 23 in Kampong Chhnang and 23 in Takeo). Some key findings are presented below: - As members of Agriculture Cooperative (AC), these farmers received direct training from DCA who further became the Training of Trainers in their respective communities. They will use the skills to train others in the future. The trainings they received were on chicken raising, dry compost, biochar, liquid compost, natural pest. There has been a notable change in livelihood diversification, particularly cabbage, kale, tomato, cucumber, and other essentials for salad, which are sold in organic supermarket. This resulted in more livelihood options of farmers. - More than 70% respondents reported implementing DRAT practice, i.e. storing water, plant trees, change crops, and prepare more seeds. The practices of chicken production, preventing chicken dying and confidence to raise chicken were some activities where farmers showed more interest. Farmers had a higher degree of attitudes towards increased soil fertility and growing plant very well. - The farmers reported increased chicken production as a result of enhanced knowledge on vaccinations, compost making, i.e. liquid compost, and natural pests. Supporting the effort described above, the cooperation with RIMES also resulted in the Farmers Field School Training of Trainers Manual, to be used by MAFF’s extension officers.
6. The project has supported the establishment of the following infrastructure: - 24 meteorological stations - 29 hydrological stations - 24 of them are hydrological stations for surface water; and 5 are hydrological stations for surface and ground water.
In addition to the above, 18 surface water-level sensors were installed.
7. MOWRAM had appointed 10 key staffs from DHRW and DOM for O&M of the AHS and AWS. They have also served as trainers for O&M for provincial level staff throughout project implementation.
8. In 2018, the government secured USD 40,000 for annual operation and maintenance of AWS and AHS. This is a good move towards securing funding for sustainability of climate data invested through the project. An internal ministerial assessment revealed the adequacy of the fund to cover O&M annually. This amount has been allocated on an annual basis for MOWRAM for O&M of the AWS and AHS stations.
The official handover of stations from the project to MOWRAM was used as a basis for building a case for more budget allocation for AWS and AHS maintenance. This fund was secured in 2019 and 2020, and MOWRAM is seeking for an increase of the O&M budget for 2021. This budget is managed by MOWRAM directly.
The project has also mapped out potential private sector partners to be engaged in climate information dissemination. A private sector engagement strategy has been developed, for use by MOWRAM as one of the instruments for future O&M of the stations. There are 10 sectors that are recommended to be explored by MOWRAM: aviation, agriculture, insurance, telecom, fisheries, water resources, energy, construction, tourism and mining. Details of recommended actions are provided in the report.
